metadata.notes: Sub-Pillars and Branches defined. Ready for Topic Domain generation.

pillar.title: Systems, Infrastructure, Technology and Operations
pillar.definition: The non-human systems that make anesthesia possible: facilities, OR operations, workflows, IT, cybersecurity, anesthesia machines, monitors, supply chain, turnover processes, and documentation systems. This pillar maps both the physical and digital infrastructure that enables safe anesthesia delivery and the operational systems that drive efficiency and quality.
inclusion_tests: Is this about how the environment, technology, or system functions so anesthesia care can occur?
Is this about physical infrastructure (OR layout, gas pipelines, HVAC, electrical)?
Is this about equipment (anesthesia machines, monitors, infusion pumps, lifecycle management)?
Is this about IT systems (AIMS, EHR integration, device connectivity, networks)?
Is this about cybersecurity (device security, network segmentation, data protection)?
Is this about supply chain (ADCs, inventory, controlled substances, pharmacy systems)?
Is this about operational workflow (turnover time, scheduling, efficiency, quality systems)?
exclusion_tests: Clinical decision-making, patient physiology, drug administration protocols → Pillar 1
CRNA/MDA roles, scope of practice, training pathways, credentialing authority → Pillar 2
State supervision laws, CMS regulations, malpractice liability, DEA compliance → Pillar 4
Contracts, billing, RVUs, compensation structures, business entity formation → Pillar 5
Education methods, research studies, evidence-based guidelines, AI innovation → Pillar 6
Career paths, W2→1099 transitions, leadership development, job market dynamics → Pillar 7
Burnout, OR politics, work-life balance, DEI, professional culture, identity → Pillar 8

sub_pillars.title: Physical Infrastructure and Facility Systems
sub_pillars.definition: The built environment and utility systems that enable anesthesia delivery: OR design and layout, medical gas pipelines, electrical systems, HVAC and infection control, lighting, and communication infrastructure. This sub-pillar also covers the distinct characteristics of different facility types—academic medical centers, community hospitals, ambulatory surgery centers, office-based settings, and mobile anesthesia—and how infrastructure scales across these environments.

branches.title: OR Design, Layout and Physical Space
branches.definition: The architectural and ergonomic design of operating rooms and anesthesia workspaces, including room dimensions, equipment positioning, sterile zones, workflow optimization, and adjacency to support areas.
branches.lens: Understanding how physical space design affects safety, efficiency, and clinical workflow

topic_domains.title: OR Room Dimensions and Space Standards
topic_domains.definition: Standard operating room sizes (400-600 ft²), ceiling height requirements, clearance zones, and minimum space allocations per FGI Guidelines. Includes how room dimensions affect equipment placement, team movement, and procedural safety.

topic_domains.title: Functional Zones and Sterile Field Organization
topic_domains.definition: The organization of OR space into functional zones: sterile field, instrument preparation area, anesthesia workspace, circulator zone, and support spaces. Covers traffic patterns, contamination prevention, and zone boundary management.

topic_domains.title: Anesthesia Workstation Positioning and Ergonomics
topic_domains.definition: Optimal placement of the anesthesia machine, equipment booms, monitors, supply carts, and documentation stations. Addresses ergonomic principles, line-of-sight to patient and monitors, and workflow efficiency for the anesthesia provider.

topic_domains.title: Adjacency Planning and Support Space Design
topic_domains.definition: The relationship between ORs and adjacent spaces: pre-operative holding, PACU, sterile processing, supply rooms, and control desks. Covers traffic flow patterns, patient transport routes, and efficient material movement.

topic_domains.title: Hybrid OR Design and Imaging Integration
topic_domains.definition: Special design considerations for hybrid operating rooms that combine surgery with advanced imaging (angiography, CT, MRI). Includes electromagnetic shielding, equipment clearances, and radiation protection infrastructure.

topic_domains.title: Human Factors and Workflow-Optimized Design
topic_domains.definition: Application of human factors engineering to OR design: standardized room orientations, lean layout principles, parallel workflow models (pit crew approach), and design features that reduce errors and improve team performance.

branches.title: Medical Gas, Vacuum and Utility Systems
branches.definition: The pipeline infrastructure that delivers oxygen, nitrous oxide, medical air, suction vacuum, and waste anesthetic gas disposal (WAGD) to the anesthesia workstation, including bulk sources, zone valves, outlet connections, and alarm systems.
branches.lens: Understanding the utility backbone that makes gas delivery and scavenging possible

topic_domains.title: Medical Gas Sources and Distribution Architecture
topic_domains.definition: Bulk storage systems (liquid oxygen, cylinder banks), manifold configurations, main supply lines, riser diagrams, and zone valve placement. Covers how medical gases travel from source to point of use throughout the facility.

topic_domains.title: Pipeline Pressure Regulation and Delivery Standards
topic_domains.definition: Pressure specifications for medical gases (50 psi for O₂/air/N₂O, 25 psi for vacuum), regulator staging, pressure relief systems, and NFPA 99 compliance requirements for safe gas delivery.

topic_domains.title: Outlet Systems and Connection Standards
topic_domains.definition: Wall and ceiling outlet configurations, Diameter Index Safety System (DISS) connectors, color coding standards, quick-connect fittings, and the pin-index safety system for cylinders. Covers how outlets prevent misconnection.

topic_domains.title: Vacuum and Suction Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Central vacuum system design, pump configurations, receiver tanks, surgical vs clinical suction levels, and distribution to OR outlets. Includes capacity planning and redundancy requirements.

topic_domains.title: Waste Anesthetic Gas Disposal (WAGD) Systems
topic_domains.definition: Scavenging system infrastructure that removes waste anesthetic gases from the OR environment. Covers passive vs active scavenging, dedicated WAGD vacuum, interface connections, and OSHA/NIOSH exposure limits.

topic_domains.title: Medical Gas Alarm and Monitoring Systems
topic_domains.definition: Central alarm panels, area alarm systems, zone monitoring, pressure sensors, and alert protocols for medical gas system failures. Covers alarm prioritization, staff notification, and emergency response procedures.

branches.title: Electrical Power, Environmental Control and Safety Systems
branches.definition: The electrical infrastructure (isolated power systems, line-isolation monitors, emergency generators, UPS) and environmental systems (HVAC, ventilation, positive pressure, temperature/humidity control, lighting) that maintain a safe and controlled OR environment.
branches.lens: Understanding the environmental and power systems that protect patients and enable uninterrupted care

topic_domains.title: Isolated Power Systems and Electrical Safety
topic_domains.definition: Isolated power system (IPS) design for wet procedure locations, line-isolation monitors (LIM), ground fault protection, and electrical safety in the OR environment. Covers NEC and NFPA 99 requirements for anesthetizing locations.

topic_domains.title: Emergency Power and Backup Systems
topic_domains.definition: On-site generator systems, automatic transfer switches, uninterruptible power supplies (UPS), and emergency power outlet identification (red receptacles). Covers NFPA 110 requirements and critical load prioritization.

topic_domains.title: HVAC System Design and Air Filtration
topic_domains.definition: Air handling unit configurations, high-efficiency filtration (HEPA, MERV 14+), air changes per hour (15-20+ ACH), and ductwork design for OR ventilation. Covers ASHRAE 170 standards and infection control requirements.

topic_domains.title: Positive Pressure and Laminar Airflow Patterns
topic_domains.definition: Maintaining positive pressure differentials between OR and adjacent spaces, laminar (unidirectional) flow from ceiling diffusers, low-wall exhaust placement, and airflow visualization. Covers contamination prevention principles.

topic_domains.title: Temperature, Humidity and Climate Control
topic_domains.definition: OR temperature setpoints (68-75°F), humidity ranges (30-60%), independent zone controls, and the impact of climate on patient safety, infection rates, and fire risk. Covers monitoring and adjustment capabilities.

topic_domains.title: Surgical and Ambient Lighting Systems
topic_domains.definition: LED surgical light technology, boom and ceiling track mounting, shadow reduction, color rendering, sterile handle controls, and ambient room lighting. Covers redundancy requirements and battery backup for critical lighting.

topic_domains.title: Communication and Integration Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Intercom and nurse call systems, video conferencing links, emergency code buttons, paging integration, and data network connections in the OR. Covers how communication systems support team coordination and emergency response.

branches.title: Facility Types and Setting-Specific Infrastructure
branches.definition: The distinct infrastructure characteristics of different anesthesia care settings: academic medical centers, community hospitals, ambulatory surgery centers, office-based anesthesia, mobile anesthesia, procedural suites, and rural versus urban facilities.
branches.lens: Understanding how infrastructure scales and adapts across different practice environments

topic_domains.title: Academic Medical Center Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Complex OR suite configurations in teaching hospitals: subspecialty rooms, hybrid imaging ORs, trauma bays, transplant facilities, ICU adjacency, multiple levels of backup systems, and infrastructure supporting education and research.

topic_domains.title: Community Hospital OR Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Standard OR suite design for community hospitals: typical 2-6 room configurations, general-purpose room design, standard equipment complement, and appropriate backup system capacity for mid-acuity surgical services.

topic_domains.title: Ambulatory Surgery Center Design and Requirements
topic_domains.definition: ASC-specific infrastructure: streamlined suite design (4-8 rooms), efficient patient flow layouts, fast turnover optimization, CMS and accreditation requirements (AAAHC, AAAASF), and scaled utility systems.

topic_domains.title: Office-Based Anesthesia Facility Requirements
topic_domains.definition: Infrastructure requirements for anesthesia in physician or dental offices: procedure room retrofitting, portable oxygen systems, basic monitoring capabilities, state regulatory requirements, and minimum safety standards.

topic_domains.title: Mobile and Dental Anesthesia Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Equipment and infrastructure for mobile anesthesia services: portable anesthesia machines, cylinder gas systems (E and J-size), battery-powered monitors, vehicle-based setups, and communication systems for remote locations.

topic_domains.title: Procedural Suite Infrastructure
topic_domains.definition: Infrastructure characteristics of non-OR procedural areas: cardiac catheterization labs, endoscopy suites, interventional radiology, and freestanding emergency departments. Covers anesthesia-specific requirements in these settings.

topic_domains.title: Rural and Critical Access Hospital Considerations
topic_domains.definition: Unique infrastructure challenges in rural settings: multi-purpose room design, limited redundancy, Critical Access Hospital (CAH) designations, off-grid contingencies, and tele-anesthesia support infrastructure.

sub_pillars.title: Anesthesia Equipment and Medical Device Ecosystem
sub_pillars.definition: The devices and equipment used to deliver and monitor anesthesia care: anesthesia machines and workstations, physiologic monitors, infusion pumps, airway devices, point-of-care analyzers, and specialty equipment. This sub-pillar encompasses the complete equipment lifecycle from capital planning and procurement through installation, preventive maintenance, calibration, repairs, and end-of-life replacement.

branches.title: Anesthesia Machine Architecture and Function
branches.definition: The core components and operating principles of anesthesia machines and workstations: high-pressure, intermediate-pressure, and low-pressure circuits; flowmeters and vaporizers; breathing circuits and ventilators; scavenging systems; and integrated safety features.
branches.lens: Understanding how the anesthesia machine delivers gases and ventilation safely

topic_domains.title: High-Pressure System and Cylinder Supply
topic_domains.definition: Cylinder yokes, hanger assemblies, pin-index safety system (PISS), cylinder pressure gauges, and two-stage regulators that reduce cylinder pressure from ~2200 psi to intermediate pressure. Covers backup oxygen supply and cylinder management.

topic_domains.title: Intermediate-Pressure System and Pipeline Interface
topic_domains.definition: Pipeline inlet connections (DISS), second-stage regulators, ventilator driving gas supply, fail-safe valves, pipeline pressure gauges, and oxygen flush valves. Covers how the machine interfaces with facility gas supplies.

topic_domains.title: Low-Pressure System and Flowmeter Bank
topic_domains.definition: Flow control valves, glass rotameter tubes, electronic flow sensors, oxygen ratio monitoring, and the common gas outlet. Covers gas mixing principles and the sequence of components in the low-pressure circuit.

topic_domains.title: Vaporizer Technology and Agent Delivery
topic_domains.definition: Variable bypass vaporizer design, temperature and flow compensation, agent-specific keyed filling systems, interlock mechanisms, and desflurane heated vaporizers. Covers accurate delivery of volatile anesthetic agents.

topic_domains.title: Breathing Circuits and Circle System Design
topic_domains.definition: Circle system components: CO₂ absorber canisters (soda lime), unidirectional valves, reservoir bag, adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve, fresh gas inlet, and Y-piece. Covers rebreathing principles and circuit configurations.

topic_domains.title: Mechanical Ventilators and Ventilation Modes
topic_domains.definition: Bellows and piston-driven ventilators, driving gas mechanisms, fresh gas decoupling, volume and pressure control modes, SIMV, pressure support, and PEEP. Covers ventilator settings and their clinical implications.

topic_domains.title: Safety Systems, Alarms and Machine Checkout
topic_domains.definition: Oxygen failure alarm (fail-safe), hypoxic guard systems, high/low pressure alarms, apnea alarms, agent analyzers, and pre-use checkout procedures. Covers ASA machine check recommendations and daily verification protocols.

branches.title: Physiologic Monitoring Systems
branches.definition: The monitors and sensors that track patient status during anesthesia: multi-parameter monitors (ECG, SpO₂, NIBP, EtCO₂, temperature), invasive pressure monitoring, neuromuscular and depth-of-anesthesia monitors, alarm systems, and data integration with clinical records.
branches.lens: Understanding the monitoring ecosystem that provides real-time patient data

topic_domains.title: Multi-Parameter Monitor Architecture and Configuration
topic_domains.definition: Modular monitor design, parameter modules, display configurations, trend storage, and network connectivity. Covers how monitors are configured for different clinical environments and integrated with clinical information systems.

topic_domains.title: Cardiac Rhythm and ECG Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: ECG lead configurations (3-lead, 5-lead, 12-lead), electrode placement, arrhythmia detection algorithms, ST-segment analysis, and artifact management. Covers cardiac monitoring standards for anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Oxygenation Monitoring: Pulse Oximetry and Capnography
topic_domains.definition: Pulse oximeter technology (SpO₂), probe types, motion artifact rejection, capnograph waveform analysis, mainstream vs sidestream sampling, and end-tidal CO₂ interpretation. Covers respiratory monitoring fundamentals.

topic_domains.title: Blood Pressure Monitoring Systems
topic_domains.definition: Non-invasive blood pressure (NIBP) oscillometry, cuff sizing, measurement intervals, invasive arterial line setup, pressure transducers, zeroing and leveling, and waveform analysis. Covers hemodynamic monitoring technology.

topic_domains.title: Temperature and Neuromuscular Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Temperature probe types (esophageal, nasopharyngeal, skin), core vs peripheral monitoring, train-of-four (TOF) stimulators, acceleromyography, and quantitative neuromuscular monitoring. Covers perioperative thermoregulation and paralysis assessment.

topic_domains.title: Depth of Anesthesia and Processed EEG Monitors
topic_domains.definition: Bispectral index (BIS) monitoring, entropy monitors, patient state index (PSI), processed EEG algorithms, electrode placement, and clinical interpretation. Covers technology for assessing anesthetic depth and awareness prevention.

branches.title: Infusion Systems and Point-of-Care Devices
branches.definition: Smart infusion pumps with drug libraries, syringe drivers, patient-controlled analgesia systems, and point-of-care testing devices (blood gas analyzers, glucose meters, coagulation testers) used in anesthesia care.
branches.lens: Understanding drug delivery technology and rapid diagnostic devices at the bedside

topic_domains.title: Smart Infusion Pump Technology and Drug Libraries
topic_domains.definition: Large-volume infusion pumps with dose error reduction software (DERS), drug library configuration, hard and soft limits, barcode scanning integration, and wireless connectivity for pump management.

topic_domains.title: Syringe Drivers and Target-Controlled Infusion
topic_domains.definition: Syringe pump mechanisms, TCI pharmacokinetic models (Marsh, Schnider, Minto), effect-site targeting, and total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) delivery systems. Covers precision drug delivery for anesthetic agents.

topic_domains.title: Patient-Controlled Analgesia Systems
topic_domains.definition: PCA pump programming, demand dosing, lockout intervals, continuous background infusions, and safety features. Covers technology for patient-controlled pain management in the perioperative period.

topic_domains.title: Blood Gas and Electrolyte Analyzers
topic_domains.definition: Point-of-care blood gas analysis, electrode technology, sample handling, quality control requirements, and result interpretation. Covers rapid assessment of oxygenation, ventilation, and acid-base status.

topic_domains.title: Point-of-Care Coagulation and Hemoglobin Testing
topic_domains.definition: Thromboelastography (TEG/ROTEM), ACT monitors, platelet function analyzers, and non-invasive hemoglobin measurement. Covers rapid coagulation and hematology testing for perioperative decision-making.

branches.title: Airway, Specialty and Emergency Equipment
branches.definition: Airway management devices (video laryngoscopes, fiberoptic bronchoscopes, supraglottic airways), ultrasound for regional anesthesia, difficult airway carts, malignant hyperthermia carts, defibrillators, and other specialty or emergency equipment.
branches.lens: Understanding specialized tools for airway management, regional techniques, and emergency response

topic_domains.title: Video Laryngoscopy Systems
topic_domains.definition: Video laryngoscope platforms (GlideScope, C-MAC, McGrath), blade geometries, display systems, recording capabilities, and reprocessing requirements. Covers technology that enhances visualization during intubation.

topic_domains.title: Fiberoptic Bronchoscopes and Advanced Airway Devices
topic_domains.definition: Flexible fiberoptic and video bronchoscopes, light sources, working channels, reprocessing protocols, and adjunct devices for awake intubation. Covers equipment for managing anticipated difficult airways.

topic_domains.title: Supraglottic Airways and Rescue Devices
topic_domains.definition: Laryngeal mask airways (LMA), i-gel, intubating LMAs, sizing considerations, and rescue airway devices (bougies, airway exchange catheters). Covers the equipment spectrum for supraglottic ventilation and rescue.

topic_domains.title: Ultrasound Systems for Regional Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: Portable ultrasound machines, high-frequency linear probes, needle visualization technology, image optimization, and machine presets for nerve block procedures. Covers equipment enabling ultrasound-guided regional techniques.

topic_domains.title: Difficult Airway Cart Organization and Contents
topic_domains.definition: Standardized difficult airway cart design, essential contents (videolaryngoscopes, FOB, supraglottic airways, surgical airway kit), organization principles, and readiness verification protocols.

topic_domains.title: Emergency Equipment: MH Cart, Defibrillators, Crash Carts
topic_domains.definition: Malignant hyperthermia cart contents and organization (dantrolene, cooling supplies), defibrillator technology and pad placement, crash cart standardization per ACLS guidelines, and readiness inspection protocols.

branches.title: Equipment Lifecycle Management
branches.definition: The complete lifecycle of anesthesia equipment: capital planning and procurement, vendor selection and GPO contracts, installation and acceptance testing, preventive maintenance and calibration, repairs and service contracts, asset tracking, and end-of-life replacement.
branches.lens: Understanding how equipment is acquired, maintained, and retired over time

topic_domains.title: Capital Planning and Budget Justification
topic_domains.definition: Capital equipment budgeting cycles, needs assessment, clinical justification, total cost of ownership analysis, and ROI calculations for anesthesia equipment acquisition. Covers navigating hospital capital processes.

topic_domains.title: Procurement, Vendor Selection and GPO Utilization
topic_domains.definition: Request for proposal (RFP) processes, vendor evaluation criteria, group purchasing organization (GPO) contracts, standardization benefits, and negotiation strategies for equipment purchases.

topic_domains.title: Installation, Commissioning and Acceptance Testing
topic_domains.definition: Equipment installation planning, integration with facility infrastructure, biomedical engineering acceptance testing, performance verification, and documentation requirements before clinical use.

topic_domains.title: Preventive Maintenance and Calibration Protocols
topic_domains.definition: Scheduled maintenance programs, manufacturer-recommended PM intervals, calibration procedures for sensors and analyzers, maintenance documentation, and CMMS tracking. Covers keeping equipment in safe operating condition.

topic_domains.title: Asset Tracking and Inventory Systems
topic_domains.definition: Equipment identification systems (barcodes, RFID), asset databases, location tracking, utilization monitoring, and integration with hospital inventory management platforms.

topic_domains.title: Obsolescence Planning and Equipment Replacement
topic_domains.definition: Equipment lifecycle analysis, replacement cycle planning (8-15 years for major devices), obsolescence indicators, legacy system risks, disposal and decommissioning procedures, and technology refresh strategies.

sub_pillars.title: Information Technology, Clinical Informatics and Cybersecurity
sub_pillars.definition: The digital systems that capture, process, protect, and transmit anesthesia data: Anesthesia Information Management Systems (AIMS), EHR integration, device connectivity and interoperability, network architecture, clinical decision support, and OR scheduling software. This sub-pillar also addresses the growing domain of cybersecurity—device vulnerabilities, network segmentation, patch management, threat detection, and regulatory compliance for data protection.

branches.title: Anesthesia Information Management and EHR Integration
branches.definition: Anesthesia Information Management Systems (AIMS) that capture vital signs, document medication administration, and generate the anesthesia record, including integration with hospital EHR platforms, clinical decision support, and barcode medication administration.
branches.lens: Understanding the clinical documentation and decision support systems for anesthesia

topic_domains.title: AIMS Platform Architecture and Core Functions
topic_domains.definition: How Anesthesia Information Management Systems are structured: data capture modules, charting interfaces, record generation, trend displays, and case management. Covers major platforms (Epic Anesthesia, Cerner, legacy systems) and their core capabilities.

topic_domains.title: EHR Integration and Bidirectional Data Exchange
topic_domains.definition: How AIMS integrates with hospital electronic health records: patient demographics, orders, lab results, allergy data, and discharge summaries. Covers interface standards, data synchronization, and seamless workflow between systems.

topic_domains.title: Automated Vital Signs Capture and Device Documentation
topic_domains.definition: Automatic ingestion of physiologic data from monitors and anesthesia machines into the electronic record. Covers data validation, artifact handling, charting intervals, and the transition from manual to automated documentation.

topic_domains.title: Clinical Decision Support in Anesthesia Systems
topic_domains.definition: Embedded alerts, reminders, and clinical pathways within AIMS: antibiotic timing alerts, drug interaction warnings, protocol compliance prompts, and ERAS pathway integration. Covers configuration and effectiveness of CDS tools.

topic_domains.title: Barcode Medication Administration for Anesthesia
topic_domains.definition: BCMA systems adapted for anesthesia workflow: syringe barcode scanning, medication verification, documentation automation, and error prevention. Covers implementation challenges and workarounds in the OR environment.

topic_domains.title: Reporting, Analytics and Quality Metrics Extraction
topic_domains.definition: Using AIMS data for quality reporting, outcome analysis, and performance dashboards. Covers data extraction, registry reporting (NACOR), benchmarking, and leveraging anesthesia data for quality improvement.

branches.title: Device Connectivity and Interoperability
branches.definition: How anesthesia devices (monitors, machines, pumps) connect and communicate with clinical information systems, including interface engines, device gateways, data standards (HL7, IEEE 11073, FHIR), and middleware solutions.
branches.lens: Understanding how devices share data with each other and with clinical systems

topic_domains.title: Medical Device Interface Standards
topic_domains.definition: Data communication standards for medical devices: HL7 v2.x messaging, IEEE 11073 (SDC), ASTM standards, and emerging HL7 FHIR for device data. Covers how standards enable (or limit) device interoperability.

topic_domains.title: Device Gateways and Middleware Solutions
topic_domains.definition: Interface engines and middleware that translate device data for clinical systems: Capsule, Cerner CareAware, Philips IntelliBridge, and similar platforms. Covers gateway architecture, configuration, and troubleshooting.

topic_domains.title: Monitor and Anesthesia Machine Connectivity
topic_domains.definition: How physiologic monitors and anesthesia workstations connect to networks and clinical systems: serial, USB, Ethernet, and wireless connections. Covers vendor-specific integration approaches and data output formats.

topic_domains.title: Infusion Pump Integration and Auto-Documentation
topic_domains.definition: Connecting smart infusion pumps to AIMS for automatic drug administration documentation: pump-to-record integration, rate capture, drug identification, and closed-loop documentation workflows.

topic_domains.title: Interoperability Challenges and Emerging Solutions
topic_domains.definition: Current limitations in device interoperability: proprietary protocols, alarm integration gaps, and unfulfilled promises of smart alarms. Covers IHE PCD profiles, FDA guidance, and the path toward true plug-and-play interoperability.

branches.title: Network Infrastructure and System Architecture
branches.definition: The IT infrastructure supporting anesthesia operations: wired and wireless networks, VLANs, servers and cloud platforms, redundancy and failover systems, OR scheduling software, and real-time location systems (RTLS).
branches.lens: Understanding the network and computing foundation that enables clinical IT systems

topic_domains.title: Clinical Network Architecture and Segmentation
topic_domains.definition: Network topology for perioperative areas: VLANs separating medical devices from administrative traffic, firewall placement, network switches, and traffic prioritization for clinical data. Covers design principles for reliable clinical networks.

topic_domains.title: Wireless Infrastructure for OR Environments
topic_domains.definition: WiFi network design for operating rooms: access point placement, signal coverage challenges, interference management, and bandwidth requirements for mobile devices and wireless monitors.

topic_domains.title: Server Infrastructure and Cloud Platforms
topic_domains.definition: Computing infrastructure for AIMS and clinical systems: on-premises servers, virtualization (VMware), database clustering, and migration to cloud platforms (Azure, AWS). Covers hybrid architectures and SaaS models.

topic_domains.title: Redundancy, Failover and Downtime Management
topic_domains.definition: Business continuity for clinical systems: server clustering, automatic failover, UPS for network equipment, and downtime procedures. Covers maintaining anesthesia documentation capability during system outages.

topic_domains.title: Real-Time Location Systems (RTLS) in Perioperative Settings
topic_domains.definition: RTLS technology for tracking equipment, patients, and staff: RFID, Bluetooth beacons, Ultra-Wideband (UWB), and integration with OR management systems. Covers use cases from equipment finding to patient flow tracking.

branches.title: Cybersecurity, Data Protection and Compliance
branches.definition: Security of medical devices and networks: vulnerability management, network segmentation, patch management, threat detection and response, access control and authentication, data encryption, HIPAA compliance, and FDA cybersecurity requirements including SBOM.
branches.lens: Understanding how anesthesia systems are protected from cyber threats and data breaches

topic_domains.title: Medical Device Security Fundamentals
topic_domains.definition: Cybersecurity risks specific to anesthesia devices: embedded operating systems, known vulnerabilities (e.g., GE Aestiva alerts), attack vectors, and the unique challenges of securing life-critical medical equipment.

topic_domains.title: Network Segmentation and Access Control
topic_domains.definition: Isolating medical devices from general network traffic: VLAN design, firewall rules, network access control (NAC), and microsegmentation strategies. Covers implementing CISA recommendations for device isolation.

topic_domains.title: Vulnerability and Patch Management
topic_domains.definition: Managing device vulnerabilities and software updates: CVE tracking, SBOM (Software Bill of Materials) requirements, vendor patch coordination, and testing procedures. Covers FDA 2025 cybersecurity requirements and 30-day disclosure rules.

topic_domains.title: Threat Detection and Incident Response
topic_domains.definition: Monitoring for cyber threats in clinical environments: SIEM deployment, medical device-specific security platforms (CyberMDX, Medigate), anomaly detection, and incident response procedures for OR network events.

topic_domains.title: Authentication and Identity Management
topic_domains.definition: Access control for clinical systems: badge authentication, two-factor authentication (2FA), single sign-on (SSO), session timeouts, and physical security for network infrastructure. Covers balancing security with clinical workflow.

topic_domains.title: HIPAA Compliance and Data Protection
topic_domains.definition: Protecting patient data in anesthesia systems: encryption at rest and in transit (AES, TLS), audit logging, access monitoring, and HIPAA security rule compliance. Covers privacy requirements for anesthesia records and device data.

sub_pillars.title: Supply Chain, Workflow and Operational Quality Systems
sub_pillars.definition: The operational systems that ensure resource availability, workflow efficiency, and quality assurance: automated dispensing cabinets, controlled substance management, inventory and pharmacy systems, OR scheduling and turnover optimization, Lean/Six Sigma process engineering, incident reporting, quality dashboards, disaster preparedness, and safety infrastructure including fire and radiation protection. This sub-pillar maps how operations are engineered for efficiency and how quality and safety systems provide resilience and continuous improvement.

branches.title: Medication Supply and Automated Dispensing
branches.definition: Automated dispensing cabinets (ADCs), controlled substance management and diversion monitoring, anesthesia medication carts and trays, and integration with pharmacy systems for secure, efficient drug access.
branches.lens: Understanding how medications are stored, dispensed, tracked, and secured

topic_domains.title: Automated Dispensing Cabinet Technology and Operations
topic_domains.definition: ADC platforms (Pyxis, Omnicell) for perioperative medication access: cabinet configurations, user authentication (badge, biometric), transaction logging, and restocking workflows. Covers how ADCs streamline medication management in anesthesia.

topic_domains.title: Controlled Substance Security and Access Controls
topic_domains.definition: Security features for Schedule II-V medications in ADCs: locked compartments, dual-witness requirements, override protocols, and count verification. Covers regulatory requirements and workflow design for controlled substance access.

topic_domains.title: Diversion Detection and Monitoring Systems
topic_domains.definition: Software systems for detecting drug diversion: pattern analysis, wasting discrepancy alerts, usage benchmarking, and investigation triggers. Covers platforms like Omnicell Safeguard and RxAuditor and their role in protecting patients and providers.

topic_domains.title: Anesthesia Medication Cart Standardization
topic_domains.definition: Design and organization of anesthesia medication carts and trays: standardized layouts, pre-filled syringes, barcode labeling, and cart exchange systems. Covers optimizing medication availability while maintaining safety.

topic_domains.title: ADC-Pharmacy Integration and Restocking Workflows
topic_domains.definition: Integration between ADCs and pharmacy information systems: automatic reorder triggers, pharmacist verification, restocking schedules, and inventory synchronization. Covers maintaining medication availability across perioperative areas.

branches.title: Inventory, Supply Chain and Resource Management
branches.definition: Supply ordering and inventory systems, par level management, just-in-time delivery, vendor and GPO relationships, recall and expiry tracking, and resource allocation for anesthesia supplies and disposables.
branches.lens: Understanding how supplies flow from vendor to point of care

topic_domains.title: Inventory Management Systems and Par Level Optimization
topic_domains.definition: Software systems for tracking anesthesia supplies: ERP integration, par level setting based on case mix, automatic reorder points, and consumption analytics. Covers balancing availability against carrying costs.

topic_domains.title: Just-in-Time Delivery and Kanban Systems
topic_domains.definition: Lean inventory approaches for anesthesia supplies: Kanban card systems, two-bin replenishment, just-in-time delivery from central supply, and minimizing OR storage requirements while preventing stockouts.

topic_domains.title: Vendor Relationships and GPO Contract Utilization
topic_domains.definition: Managing supplier relationships for anesthesia supplies: group purchasing organization (GPO) contract leverage, vendor-managed inventory (VMI), sole-source vs multi-source strategies, and negotiation approaches.

topic_domains.title: Recall and Expiration Management
topic_domains.definition: Systems for tracking product recalls and expiration dates: lot number tracking, automated expiry alerts, recall notification workflows, and quarantine procedures. Covers preventing use of compromised or expired supplies.

topic_domains.title: Shortage Management and Alternate Sourcing
topic_domains.definition: Responding to drug and supply shortages: alternative product identification, allocation strategies, therapeutic substitution protocols, and communication with clinical staff. Covers maintaining care continuity during supply disruptions.

branches.title: OR Scheduling and Case Flow Optimization
branches.definition: OR scheduling systems, block management, case booking and add-on workflows, first-case on-time starts, patient throughput from pre-op through PACU, and digital dashboards for real-time case status.
branches.lens: Understanding how cases are scheduled and patients flow through the perioperative environment

topic_domains.title: Block Scheduling Systems and Allocation
topic_domains.definition: Block time allocation models: surgeon and service block assignments, release time policies, block utilization metrics, and reallocation strategies. Covers optimizing OR capacity through effective block management.

topic_domains.title: Case Booking and Add-On Workflows
topic_domains.definition: Electronic case scheduling systems: booking interfaces, required data elements, add-on case management, and coordination between scheduling staff, surgeons, and anesthesia. Covers streamlining the case booking process.

topic_domains.title: First-Case On-Time Starts and Delay Tracking
topic_domains.definition: Systems for achieving and measuring on-time starts: delay reason coding, accountability tracking, pre-operative readiness verification, and improvement initiatives. Covers the operational and financial impact of delays.

topic_domains.title: Patient Flow from Pre-Op Through PACU
topic_domains.definition: Managing patient throughput across perioperative phases: pre-op preparation workflows, OR-to-PACU handoffs, discharge readiness criteria, and bottleneck identification. Covers optimizing the patient journey.

topic_domains.title: OR Dashboards and Real-Time Status Displays
topic_domains.definition: Digital displays for OR management: case progress tracking, room status boards, delay alerts, and command center visualizations. Covers how real-time information enables proactive management of OR operations.

branches.title: Process Engineering and Workflow Efficiency
branches.definition: Lean and Six Sigma methodologies applied to anesthesia operations, turnover time optimization, parallel processing, value stream mapping, communication workflows (huddles, SBAR), and continuous improvement initiatives.
branches.lens: Understanding how operations are engineered for efficiency and waste reduction

topic_domains.title: Lean Methodology in Perioperative Operations
topic_domains.definition: Applying Lean principles to anesthesia and OR operations: waste identification (muda), 5S workplace organization, standard work, and visual management. Covers the foundation of process improvement in perioperative settings.

topic_domains.title: Turnover Time Optimization and Parallel Processing
topic_domains.definition: Engineering efficient room turnovers: parallel task execution (pit crew model), role-specific checklists, RTLS-triggered workflows, and measurement methodologies. Covers reducing non-operative time between cases.

topic_domains.title: Value Stream Mapping and Waste Reduction
topic_domains.definition: Analyzing and improving perioperative workflows: value stream mapping techniques, identifying non-value-added steps, cycle time analysis, and redesigning processes for efficiency.

topic_domains.title: Communication Workflows: Huddles and Handoffs
topic_domains.definition: Structured communication systems for perioperative teams: pre-operative huddles, surgical briefings, SBAR handoff protocols, and shift-change communication. Covers ensuring information continuity and team alignment.

topic_domains.title: Continuous Improvement and PDSA Cycles
topic_domains.definition: Sustaining operational improvements: Plan-Do-Study-Act methodology, improvement project management, metric tracking, and building a culture of continuous improvement in anesthesia operations.

branches.title: Quality, Safety and Continuity Systems
branches.definition: Incident reporting and root cause analysis, quality dashboards and performance metrics, ERAS pathway infrastructure, disaster preparedness and downtime procedures, fire and radiation safety protocols, and emergency equipment readiness.
branches.lens: Understanding the systems that monitor quality, ensure safety, and maintain operational resilience

topic_domains.title: Incident Reporting Systems and Safety Culture
topic_domains.definition: Electronic incident reporting platforms (RLDatix, ECRI SAFER): event categorization, anonymous reporting options, trending analysis, and good-catch programs. Covers building a just culture that encourages safety reporting.

topic_domains.title: Root Cause Analysis and Corrective Actions
topic_domains.definition: Investigating adverse events and near-misses: RCA methodology, fishbone diagrams, failure mode analysis (FMEA), and implementing sustainable corrective actions. Covers systematic approaches to preventing recurrence.

topic_domains.title: Quality Dashboards and Performance Metrics
topic_domains.definition: Monitoring anesthesia quality indicators: PONV rates, hypothermia incidence, antibiotic timing compliance, and other perioperative metrics. Covers dashboard design, benchmarking, and using data to drive improvement.

topic_domains.title: ERAS Pathway Infrastructure and Implementation
topic_domains.definition: Systems supporting Enhanced Recovery After Surgery programs: standardized order sets, patient education platforms, outcome tracking, and multi-disciplinary coordination infrastructure. Covers the operational backbone of ERAS.

topic_domains.title: Disaster Preparedness and Downtime Procedures
topic_domains.definition: Operational continuity planning: power failure protocols, IT system downtime procedures, mass casualty response, and emergency communication systems. Covers maintaining anesthesia services during facility emergencies.

topic_domains.title: Fire Safety Systems and Prevention Protocols
topic_domains.definition: OR fire prevention infrastructure: surgical fire risk assessment, oxygen management near ignition sources, fire suppression systems, laser safety protocols, and staff training requirements. Covers the fire triangle in surgical settings.

topic_domains.title: Radiation Safety Infrastructure and Monitoring
topic_domains.definition: Radiation protection systems in perioperative areas: lead shielding, protective equipment (aprons, thyroid shields), dosimetry badge programs, ALARA principles, and regulatory compliance for fluoroscopy and hybrid OR environments.
